rOBTUx-y6.memHandModelNotes: There are very few map units that correspond geographically to this species' range.  Any units that are essentially grassland/prairie and/or woodlands within the delineated range and within the Wabash lowlands and hills type ecoregions would be acceptable.

references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B85STE01NAUS: Stebbins, R. C. 1985. A Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xiv + 336 pp.
references.W02NEW01USGP: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. 2002. Biota Information System of New Mexico. New Mexico Department of Game and Fish electronic database, BISON. Version January 2002, Santa Fe, New Mexico. Http://nmnhp.unm.edu/bisonm/bisonquery.php.
references.A07BER01SEGP: Bernstein, N.P., R.J. Richtsmeier, R.W. Black and B.R. Mongomery.  2007. Home range and philopatry in the ornate box turtle, Terrapene ornata ornata, in Iowa. Am. Midl. Nat. 157: 162-174.
references.A03CON01SEGP: Converse, S.J. and J.A. Savidge. 2003. Ambient temperature, activity, and microhabitat use by ornate box turtles (Terrapene ornata ornata). Journal of Herpetology 37:665-670.
references.R96PAI01SWGP: Painter, C. and L. Pierce. 1996. NMHerp database and General process to produce expected range shapefiles of New Mexico amphibians and reptiles.. Shapefiles and document produced to provide range and elevation estimates for NM amphibians and reptiles.  Internal report.  Pps. 66..
references.B03STE01USGP: Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
references.B99HAMUSGP: Hammerson, G. 1999.  Amphibians and reptiles in Colorado. Second edition. University Press of Colorado and Colorado Division of Wildlife.Niwot, Colorado, USA.
references.A04BOW01SEGP: Bowen, K.D., P.L. Colbert, and F.J. Janzen. 2004. Survival and recruitment in a human-impacted population of ornate box turtles, Terrapene ornata, with recommendations for conservation and management. J. Herpetol. 38:562-568.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.B96DEG01USGP: Degenhardt, W., Painter, C., and A. Price.  1996. Amphibians and reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 429 pages.

habitat_description:
From NatureServe:
Palustrine Habitat(s): Riparian
Terrestrial Habitat(s): Cropland/hedgerow, Desert, Grassland/herbaceous, Shrubland/chaparral, Woodland - Hardwood

Habitat Comments: Ornate or western box turtles inhabit prairie grassland, pasture, fields, sandhills, and open woodland. They are essentially terrestrial but sometimes enter slow, shallow streams and creek pools.  

From SWReGAP
Primarily a prairie turtle (Stebbins 1985, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). Over much of its range it inhabits treeless plains and gently rolling country grown to grass or scattered low bushes where soil is sandy (Stebbins 1985, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  Also occurs in open woodland (Stebbins 1985).  Listed as Appendix II Species (Export Permit required) (Hammerson 1999).  T. ornata are not dependent on free water (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Are most abundant in grasslands with soils suitable for burrowing (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Box turtles consistently chose microhabitats with lower moisture and soil temperature but higher ambient temperatures than those at the Meterological Station (Nieuwolt 1996). Normally don't occupy elevations above 2100 m (Degenhardt et al. 1996). The elevation range is 0-2,200m (Stebbins 1985, Degenhardt et al. 1996). T. ornata occurs in southeastern Arizona (Stebbins 2003). It is found in eastern Colorado (Hammerson 1999, Stebbins 2003). It is present in New Mexico except in the northwest (Degenhardt et al. 1996, Stebbins 2003).
